elements.content: The reactivity of 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (H4DOBDC) with titanium­(IV) precursors was thoroughly investigated for the synthesis of metal–organic frameworks under solvothermal conditions. Four crystalline phases were isolated whose structures were studied by a combination of single-crystal or powder X-ray diffraction and solid-state NMR. The strong coordination ability of the phenolate moieties was found to favor the formation of isolated TiO6 octahedra bearing solely organic ligands in the resulting structures, unless hydrothermal conditions and precondensed inorganic precursors are used. It is worth noting that these solids strongly absorb visible light, as a consequence of the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) arising from Ti–phenolate bonds. Preliminary photocatalytic tests suggest that one compound, namely, MIL-167, presents a higher activity for hydrogen evolution than the titanium carboxylate MIL-125-NH2 but that such an effect cannot be directly correlated with its improved light absorption feature.
elements.clean_text: The reactivity of 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (H4DOBDC) with titanium(IV) precursors was thoroughly investigated for the synthesis of metal-organic frameworks under solvothermal conditions. Four crystalline phases were isolated whose structures were studied by a combination of single-crystal or powder X-ray diffraction and solid-state NMR. The strong coordination ability of the phenolate moieties was found to favor the formation of isolated TiO6 octahedra bearing solely organic ligands in the resulting structures, unless hydrothermal conditions and precondensed inorganic precursors are used. It is worth noting that these solids strongly absorb visible light, as a consequence of the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) arising from Ti-phenolate bonds. Preliminary photocatalytic tests suggest that one compound, namely, MIL-167, presents a higher activity for hydrogen evolution than the titanium carboxylate MIL-125-NH2 but that such an effect cannot be directly correlated with its improved light absorption feature.

elements.content: The reaction of 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (H4DOBDC) with titanium­(IV) precursors leads to the formation of four coordination polymers of various dimensionalities, all presenting strong absorption of light in the visible range.
elements.clean_text: The reaction of 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (H4DOBDC) with titanium(IV) precursors leads to the formation of four coordination polymers of various dimensionalities, all presenting strong absorption of light in the visible range.

elements.content: While porous coordination polymers or metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are considered to be promising candidates in various domains (gas storage, fluid separation, acid or base catalysis, and biomedicine, among others), their use as heterogeneous photocatalysts has exploded only very recently. Considering the well-established photocatalytic properties of TiO2, it seems logical to develop porous titanium-based MOFs for such applications. Precisely, photocatalytic systems based on MOFs may be beneficial because of the various combinations of oxo–metal clusters and organic linkers together with their intrinsic porosity, which facilitates the diffusion of substrates and products to the catalytic centers. Nevertheless, because of the inherent difficulty in controlling the reactivity of titanium­(IV) ions in solution (especially out of the very acidic conditions), among the numerous MOFs reported so far, those based on titanium are still very limited. If open-framework titanium bis­(phosphonates) such as MIL-22­(Ti) and MIL-25­(Ti) (MIL stands for Materials Institute Lavoisier) were discovered at the end of the 1990s, the first microporous crystalline titanium­(IV) diphosphonate, MIL-91, was reported by some of us only in 2006, followed by the titanium­(IV) terephthalate MIL-125. If MIL-91­(Ti) bears Tancoite-type chains of corner-sharing metal octahedra bridged by bis­(phosphonate) moieties delimiting a narrow 1D pore system, MIL-125­(Ti) is a cubic network built up from Ti8O8(OH)4 oxo clusters linked together via terephthalate linkers to define a 3D microporous system with a high surface area (S BET ∼ 1500 m2 g–1) and photocatalytic activity. Since then, a few photoactive porous titanium­(IV) carboxylates, such as the functionalized MIL-125-NH2, the porphyrinetetracarboxylate derivative PCN-22, and the flexible 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate COK-69, as well as the titanium­(III) terephthalate MIL-101, have been described. Note that these MOFs each bear different inorganic subunits, highlighting the poor degree of control of titanium polymerization in solution even in the presence of strongly complexing ligands. As an alternative to direct synthesis, postsynthetic cation exchange was also reported. Absorption of light in the visible range is a prerequisite for many photodriven applications. In the case of titanium­(IV) carboxylates, such a feature is obtained through the use of an organic ligand presenting a low highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO)–lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) gap, with light absorption thus only governed by “organic-like” electronic levels. Alternatively, TiIV–phenolate bonds are known to lead to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT), giving rise to strong absorption in the visible range. Indeed, both amorphous and crystalline titanium­(IV) phenolate open frameworks have been described since the 1990s, all presenting a deep-red color. More recently, α-hydroxycarboxylate and catecholate ligands were also considered to build up both pure titanium­(IV) and bimetallic titanium­(IV)/zinc­(II) open frameworks.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

While porous coordination polymers or metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are considered to be promising candidates in various domains (gas storage, fluid separation, acid or base catalysis, and biomedicine, among others), their use as heterogeneous photocatalysts has exploded only very recently. Considering the well-established photocatalytic properties of TiO2, it seems logical to develop porous titanium-based MOFs for such applications. Precisely, photocatalytic systems based on MOFs may be beneficial because of the various combinations of oxo-metal clusters and organic linkers together with their intrinsic porosity, which facilitates the diffusion of substrates and products to the catalytic centers. Nevertheless, because of the inherent difficulty in controlling the reactivity of titanium(IV) ions in solution (especially out of the very acidic conditions), among the numerous MOFs reported so far, those based on titanium are still very limited. If open-framework titanium bis(phosphonates) such as MIL-22(Ti) and MIL-25(Ti) (MIL stands for Materials Institute Lavoisier) were discovered at the end of the 1990s, the first microporous crystalline titanium(IV) diphosphonate, MIL-91, was reported by some of us only in 2006, followed by the titanium(IV) terephthalate MIL-125. If MIL-91(Ti) bears Tancoite-type chains of corner-sharing metal octahedra bridged by bis(phosphonate) moieties delimiting a narrow 1D pore system, MIL-125(Ti) is a cubic network built up from Ti8O8(OH)4 oxo clusters linked together via terephthalate linkers to define a 3D microporous system with a high surface area (S BET ~ 1500 m2 g-1) and photocatalytic activity. Since then, a few photoactive porous titanium(IV) carboxylates, such as the functionalized MIL-125-NH2, the porphyrinetetracarboxylate derivative PCN-22, and the flexible 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate COK-69, as well as the titanium(III) terephthalate MIL-101, have been described. Note that these MOFs each bear different inorganic subunits, highlighting the poor degree of control of titanium polymerization in solution even in the presence of strongly complexing ligands. As an alternative to direct synthesis, postsynthetic cation exchange was also reported. Absorption of light in the visible range is a prerequisite for many photodriven applications. In the case of titanium(IV) carboxylates, such a feature is obtained through the use of an organic ligand presenting a low highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO)-lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) gap, with light absorption thus only governed by "organic-like" electronic levels. Alternatively, TiIV-phenolate bonds are known to lead to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT), giving rise to strong absorption in the visible range. Indeed, both amorphous and crystalline titanium(IV) phenolate open frameworks have been described since the 1990s, all presenting a deep-red color. More recently, α-hydroxycarboxylate and catecholate ligands were also considered to build up both pure titanium(IV) and bimetallic titanium(IV)/zinc(II) open frameworks.

elements.content: 2,5-Dihydroxyterephthalic acid (H4DOBDC; ) is a typical linker to build up MOFs comprising both carboxylate–cation and phenolate–cation bonds, such as the archetypical M2(DOBDC) CPO-27 or MOF-74 (M = Ni, Co, Mg, Zn, Mn, Fe, etc.) porous solids. Upon reacting H4DOBDC with titanium­(IV) isopropoxide in acetic acid, Gao et al. isolated a layered solid formulated Ti2(HDOBDC)2(HDOBDC) (labeled NTU-9, where NTU stands for Nanyang Technological University), built up from isolated TiO6 octahedra connected through organic units acting as ditopic ligands to afford a 2D honeycomb-like network with a 6,3 topology. Very recently, Zou et al. also prepared the almost pure titanium version of CPO-27/MOF-74 by postsynthetic cation exchange. We here systematically investigated the reactivity of this specific ligand with titanium­(IV) precursors under solvothermal conditions, in order not only to obtain new open photoactive frameworks but also to expand our understanding of the chemistry of titanium. We report an in-depth characterization of a few of the resulting solids, including structure determination by either single-crystal or powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), solid-state NMR analysis, and gas sorption properties, as well as preliminary photocatalytic activity tests.
elements.clean_text: 2,5-Dihydroxyterephthalic acid (H4DOBDC; ) is a typical linker to build up MOFs comprising both carboxylate-cation and phenolate-cation bonds, such as the archetypical M2(DOBDC) CPO-27 or MOF-74 (M = Ni, Co, Mg, Zn, Mn, Fe, etc.) porous solids. Upon reacting H4DOBDC with titanium(IV) isopropoxide in acetic acid, Gao et al. isolated a layered solid formulated Ti2(HDOBDC)2(HDOBDC) (labeled NTU-9, where NTU stands for Nanyang Technological University), built up from isolated TiO6 octahedra connected through organic units acting as ditopic ligands to afford a 2D honeycomb-like network with a 6,3 topology. Very recently, Zou et al. also prepared the almost pure titanium version of CPO-27/MOF-74 by postsynthetic cation exchange. We here systematically investigated the reactivity of this specific ligand with titanium(IV) precursors under solvothermal conditions, in order not only to obtain new open photoactive frameworks but also to expand our understanding of the chemistry of titanium. We report an in-depth characterization of a few of the resulting solids, including structure determination by either single-crystal or powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), solid-state NMR analysis, and gas sorption properties, as well as preliminary photocatalytic activity tests.

elements.content: Details about the synthesis, structure determination by XRD analysis, and further characterizations [solid-state NMR, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), IR, thermodiffraction, porosimetry, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) imaging] as well as catalytic tests can be found in the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Details about the synthesis, structure determination by XRD analysis, and further characterizations [solid-state NMR, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), IR, thermodiffraction, porosimetry, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) imaging] as well as catalytic tests can be found in the Supporting Information.

elements.content: The reactivity of H4DOBDC with titanium­(IV) sources under solvothermal conditions was first evaluated using a miniaturized high-throughput setup developed by Stock, allowing the rapid screening of a broad range of synthetic conditions in a series of small reactors (<2 mL). The nature of the titanium­(IV) precursor and solvent, as well as the addition of catechol, possibly acting as a growth modulator, was found to be the key experimental parameters. Upon systematic variation of such parameters, four crystalline phases were identified, whose powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns are shown in and unit cell parameters are summarized in . The syntheses were then up-scaled in 25 mL reactors for full characterization.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis and Structure Determination

The reactivity of H4DOBDC with titanium(IV) sources under solvothermal conditions was first evaluated using a miniaturized high-throughput setup developed by Stock, allowing the rapid screening of a broad range of synthetic conditions in a series of small reactors (<2 mL). The nature of the titanium(IV) precursor and solvent, as well as the addition of catechol, possibly acting as a growth modulator, was found to be the key experimental parameters. Upon systematic variation of such parameters, four crystalline phases were identified, whose powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns are shown in  and unit cell parameters are summarized in . The syntheses were then up-scaled in 25 mL reactors for full characterization.

elements.content: Powder XRD patterns of MIL-167, MIL-168, MIL-169, and “NTU-9-like” (λ = 1.5418 Å).
elements.clean_text: 1  Powder XRD patterns of MIL-167, MIL-168, MIL-169, and "NTU-9-like" (λ = 1.5418 Å).

elements.content:
Crystallographic Parameters of the Title Solids solid formula space group cell parameters MIL-167 Ti(DOBDC)1.5(Et2MeNH)2·nH2O I4̅3d a = 22.9118(4) Å, V = 12027.6(6) Å3 MIL-168 Ti(DOBDC)(cat)(DEAH)2 Pbcn a = 16.863(1) Å, b = 13.3677(8) Å, c = 10.7622(6) Å, V = 2426.1(3) Å3 MIL-169 TiO0.5(DOBDC)(H2O)(pipH2)0.5·H2O P1̅ a = 8.10511(5) Å, b = 8.15098(5) Å, c = 9.90029(6) Å, α = 75.8518(4)°, β = 82.3596(4)°, γ = 76.9343(6)°, V = 615.707(7) Å3 “NTU-9-like” Ti(H x DOBDC)1.5(DEAH)2–1.5x ·nsolv P3̅1c a = 14.69(1) Å, c = 11.47(1) Å, V = 2144(3) Å3

DEAH = diethylammonium, pipH2 = piperazinium.

First, when using N,N-diethylformamide (DEF) as a solvent and titanium­(IV) isopropoxide as a precursor, three phases were isolated, whose structures will be described below. In pure DEF and using a ligand-to-titanium­(IV) ratio equal to 4, the first solid exhibiting a powder XRD pattern very similar to that of NTU-9 and further labeled “NTU-9-like” (Figure S2) was isolated. Upon the addition of catechol [3 equiv per titanium­(IV)], a new crystalline phase (labeled MIL-168) was obtained. The addition of methanol to the reaction medium in the absence of catechol ultimately leads to the formation of a third solid, MIL-167 (detailed synthetic conditions can be found in the Supporting Information). Note that the use of N,N-dimethylformamide as a solvent led to different crystalline phases whose crystal structures could not be solved yet. Crystallites of MIL-168 suitable for single-crystal XRD analysis using synchrotron radiation (beamline Crystal, Synchrotron Soleil, France) could be produced. MIL-167 was obtained as large, but intergrown crystallites (Figure S13), preventing any structure determination by single-crystal analysis. Additionally, “NTU-9-like” was isolated as micrometer-sized platelets (Figure S15). Both MIL-167 and “NTU-9-like” were, hence, studied by powder XRD analysis, in combination with solid-state NMR spectroscopy, to extract information about the content of the unit cell and the local environment (see the Supporting Information and below).
elements.clean_text: First, when using N,N-diethylformamide (DEF) as a solvent and titanium(IV) isopropoxide as a precursor, three phases were isolated, whose structures will be described below. In pure DEF and using a ligand-to-titanium(IV) ratio equal to 4, the first solid exhibiting a powder XRD pattern very similar to that of NTU-9 and further labeled "NTU-9-like" (Figure S2) was isolated. Upon the addition of catechol [3 equiv per titanium(IV)], a new crystalline phase (labeled MIL-168) was obtained. The addition of methanol to the reaction medium in the absence of catechol ultimately leads to the formation of a third solid, MIL-167 (detailed synthetic conditions can be found in the Supporting Information). Note that the use of N,N-dimethylformamide as a solvent led to different crystalline phases whose crystal structures could not be solved yet. Crystallites of MIL-168 suitable for single-crystal XRD analysis using synchrotron radiation (beamline Crystal, Synchrotron Soleil, France) could be produced. MIL-167 was obtained as large, but intergrown crystallites (Figure S13), preventing any structure determination by single-crystal analysis. Additionally, "NTU-9-like" was isolated as micrometer-sized platelets (Figure S15). Both MIL-167 and "NTU-9-like" were, hence, studied by powder XRD analysis, in combination with solid-state NMR spectroscopy, to extract information about the content of the unit cell and the local environment (see the Supporting Information and below).

elements.content: MIL-167 crystallizes in a cubic setting, space group I4̅3d (), with one titanium­(IV) ion on a 3-fold axis and half of a ligand in the general position (see Figure S5 for the final Rietveld refinement), hence leading to the stoichiometry of three ligands for two titanium­(IV) ions. The structure consists of isolated TiO6 octahedra, with the oxygen atoms arising solely from DOBDC ligands (a), connected to each other by the ditopic linkers through chelating six-membered rings involving both phenolic and carboxylic oxygen atoms (a) to afford a 3D chiral network exhibiting 10,3-a topology (b). Two enantiomeric networks are then interpenetrated to afford the final MIL-167 solid (b), which holds cavities of about 6–7 Å free diameter.
elements.clean_text: MIL-167 crystallizes in a cubic setting, space group I4̅3d (), with one titanium(IV) ion on a 3-fold axis and half of a ligand in the general position (see Figure S5 for the final Rietveld refinement), hence leading to the stoichiometry of three ligands for two titanium(IV) ions. The structure consists of isolated TiO6 octahedra, with the oxygen atoms arising solely from DOBDC ligands (a), connected to each other by the ditopic linkers through chelating six-membered rings involving both phenolic and carboxylic oxygen atoms (a) to afford a 3D chiral network exhibiting 10,3-a topology (b). Two enantiomeric networks are then interpenetrated to afford the final MIL-167 solid (b), which holds cavities of about 6-7 Å free diameter.

elements.content: Crystal structures. (a) Coordination sphere around the titanium­(IV) ions in both NTU-9 and MIL-167. (b and c) Coordination framework and the corresponding topological network for MIL-167 and NTU-9, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 2  Crystal structures. (a) Coordination sphere around the titanium(IV) ions in both NTU-9 and MIL-167. (b and c) Coordination framework and the corresponding topological network for MIL-167 and NTU-9, respectively.

elements.content: 1D and 2D solid-state NMR experiments were further carried out to investigate the nature of the pore content ( and S20). Both 1D 1H and 13C NMR spectra () present the signals expected for the DOBDC ligand, as well as the resonances characteristic of alkyl groups. Specifically, the signals at 9, 46, and 60 ppm on the 13C NMR spectrum (, top) were attributed to diethylmethylammonium. This is in agreement with the 2D 1H–13C and 1H–1H NMR correlation experiments (Figures S22 and S23), which indicate that all alkyl groups are close in space, hence likely belonging to a single molecular entity. Such tertiary ammonium could arise from reactions involving both solvents: DEF first degrades into diethylamine, which further reacts with methanol to generate diethylmethylamine. An acidic proton (δ ∼ 9.2 ppm) as well as a signal at 3.6 ppm attributed to the ammonium and water could also be identified on the 1H NMR spectrum (, bottom), finally yielding to the formula Ti­(DOBDC)1.5(Et2MeNH)2·nH2O, in agreement with TGA and chemical analysis (Figure S12 and Table S1).
elements.clean_text: 1D and 2D solid-state NMR experiments were further carried out to investigate the nature of the pore content ( and S20). Both 1D 1H and 13C NMR spectra () present the signals expected for the DOBDC ligand, as well as the resonances characteristic of alkyl groups. Specifically, the signals at 9, 46, and 60 ppm on the 13C NMR spectrum (, top) were attributed to diethylmethylammonium. This is in agreement with the 2D 1H-13C and 1H-1H NMR correlation experiments (Figures S22 and S23), which indicate that all alkyl groups are close in space, hence likely belonging to a single molecular entity. Such tertiary ammonium could arise from reactions involving both solvents: DEF first degrades into diethylamine, which further reacts with methanol to generate diethylmethylamine. An acidic proton (δ ~ 9.2 ppm) as well as a signal at 3.6 ppm attributed to the ammonium and water could also be identified on the 1H NMR spectrum (, bottom), finally yielding to the formula Ti(DOBDC)1.5(Et2MeNH)2⋅nH2O, in agreement with TGA and chemical analysis (Figure S12 and Table S1).

elements.content: 1H → 13C CPMAS (10 kHz) (top) and 1H MAS (30 kHz) (bottom) NMR spectra of MIL-167, MIl-168, “NTU-9-like”, and MIL-169.
elements.clean_text: 3   1H → 13C CPMAS (10 kHz) (top) and 1H MAS (30 kHz) (bottom) NMR spectra of MIL-167, MIl-168, "NTU-9-like", and MIL-169.

elements.content: In the absence of methanol in the reaction mixture, the “NTU-9-like” solid was produced. As mentioned earlier, this compound is built up from isolated TiO6 octahedra connected through three DOBDC ligands, giving rise to a 2D honeycomb layer (). Slight differences between the calculated and experimental patterns are discernible (Figure S2) and probably arise from variation of the interlayer content (although preferred orientation effects could not be ruled out). Indeed, while Gao et al. formulated the NTU-9 solid as Ti­(HDOBDC)­(H2DOBDC)0.5, signals indicating the presence of diethylammonium (DEAH) were found in the 1H and 13C NMR spectra ( and S24), suggesting a formula closer to Ti­(H x DOBDC)1.5(DEAH)2–1.5x ·nsolv (solv = H2O, DEF) for our experimental conditions.
elements.clean_text: In the absence of methanol in the reaction mixture, the "NTU-9-like" solid was produced. As mentioned earlier, this compound is built up from isolated TiO6 octahedra connected through three DOBDC ligands, giving rise to a 2D honeycomb layer (). Slight differences between the calculated and experimental patterns are discernible (Figure S2) and probably arise from variation of the interlayer content (although preferred orientation effects could not be ruled out). Indeed, while Gao et al. formulated the NTU-9 solid as Ti(HDOBDC)(H2DOBDC)0.5, signals indicating the presence of diethylammonium (DEAH) were found in the 1H and 13C NMR spectra ( and S24), suggesting a formula closer to Ti(H x DOBDC)1.5(DEAH)2-1.5x ⋅nsolv (solv = H2O, DEF) for our experimental conditions.

elements.content: Interestingly, MIL-167 and NTU-9 are built up from the same coordination motif (a) and hence, without taking into account the counterions, are simply polymorphs arising from a different alternation of the absolute configuration Δ/Λ of the neighboring octahedral metal centers. Such an occurrence of polymorphic 2D (6,3) and 3D (10,3) networks was indeed already identified by Abrahams et al. when using metal­(II) cations and 2,5-dihydroxybenzoquinone as a ligand and might be associated with a templating effect of the ammonium cations. Nevertheless, a solid similar to MIL-167 but of very poor crystallinity was obtained using a mixture of acetic acid and diethylamine as the solvent (Figure S1), indicating that the presence of the diethylmethylammonium cation is not mandatory to produce the 3D polymorph.
elements.clean_text: Interestingly, MIL-167 and NTU-9 are built up from the same coordination motif (a) and hence, without taking into account the counterions, are simply polymorphs arising from a different alternation of the absolute configuration Δ/Λ of the neighboring octahedral metal centers. Such an occurrence of polymorphic 2D (6,3) and 3D (10,3) networks was indeed already identified by Abrahams et al. when using metal(II) cations and 2,5-dihydroxybenzoquinone as a ligand and might be associated with a templating effect of the ammonium cations. Nevertheless, a solid similar to MIL-167 but of very poor crystallinity was obtained using a mixture of acetic acid and diethylamine as the solvent (Figure S1), indicating that the presence of the diethylmethylammonium cation is not mandatory to produce the 3D polymorph.

elements.content: Finally, the third compound, i.e., MIL-168, isolated in the presence of catechol (H2cat), crystallizes in an orthorhombic setting in the Pbcn space group, with an asymmetric unit consisting of one titanium ion lying on a 2-fold axis, half of a DOBC ligand, and a catechol on a 2-fold axis. It also contains a DEAH ion in the general position, thus leading to the formula Ti­(DOBDC)­(cat)­(DEAH)2, as confirmed by TGA, chemical analysis (Figure S12 and Table S1) as well as 1H and 13C NMR ( and S24). This structure is once again built up from isolated TiO6 octahedra, with the coordinating oxygen atoms arising this time from two DOBDC ligands and one catechol moiety (). This defines 1D zigzag chains running parallel to each other and separated by N–H···O hydrogen-bonded DEAH cations (Figure S7), arising again from the degradation of DEF. The surroundings of the titanium ion present thus strong similarities with those in MIL-167 and NTU-9, with solely one DOBDC ligand replaced by a catecholate one. Catechol was initially added to act as a modulator, i.e., to slow down the precipitation and improve the crystallinity of the resulting solid. Here, even the use of a minor amount of catechol (cat/DOBDC = 3/4) leads to its insertion within the structure. This is in agreement with its stronger coordination ability compared with α-hydroxycarboxylates such as DOBDC and indicates that it shall not be used as a modulator with such ligands. Furthermore, whatever the solvothermal conditions tested, exclusively structures built up from isolated TiO6 octahedra without any inorganic ligand (oxo, hydroxo, or aquo moieties) were produced. This is in sharp contrast with the case of titanium carboxylates, in which oxo or hydroxo bridges are always found. Only in the case of titanium bis­(phosphonate) systems could one obtain such a configuration, leading to pillared versions of the well-known α-TiP solid. As was already exemplified in the case of zirconium-based MOFs, the final inorganic building unit results from the competition between both types of ligands, the organic and inorganic ones. Upon switching from carboxylate to α-hydroxycarboxylate, catecholate, or phosphonates ligands, the strength of coordination increases, hence disfavoring the presence of inorganic ligands. Similar to the case of titanium phosphate chemistry under hydrothermal conditions, this effect might, of course, be counterbalanced through an increase of the pH, favoring inorganic condensation.
elements.clean_text: Finally, the third compound, i.e., MIL-168, isolated in the presence of catechol (H2cat), crystallizes in an orthorhombic setting in the Pbcn space group, with an asymmetric unit consisting of one titanium ion lying on a 2-fold axis, half of a DOBC ligand, and a catechol on a 2-fold axis. It also contains a DEAH ion in the general position, thus leading to the formula Ti(DOBDC)(cat)(DEAH)2, as confirmed by TGA, chemical analysis (Figure S12 and Table S1) as well as 1H and 13C NMR ( and S24). This structure is once again built up from isolated TiO6 octahedra, with the coordinating oxygen atoms arising this time from two DOBDC ligands and one catechol moiety (). This defines 1D zigzag chains running parallel to each other and separated by N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen-bonded DEAH cations (Figure S7), arising again from the degradation of DEF. The surroundings of the titanium ion present thus strong similarities with those in MIL-167 and NTU-9, with solely one DOBDC ligand replaced by a catecholate one. Catechol was initially added to act as a modulator, i.e., to slow down the precipitation and improve the crystallinity of the resulting solid. Here, even the use of a minor amount of catechol (cat/DOBDC = 3/4) leads to its insertion within the structure. This is in agreement with its stronger coordination ability compared with α-hydroxycarboxylates such as DOBDC and indicates that it shall not be used as a modulator with such ligands. Furthermore, whatever the solvothermal conditions tested, exclusively structures built up from isolated TiO6 octahedra without any inorganic ligand (oxo, hydroxo, or aquo moieties) were produced. This is in sharp contrast with the case of titanium carboxylates, in which oxo or hydroxo bridges are always found. Only in the case of titanium bis(phosphonate) systems could one obtain such a configuration, leading to pillared versions of the well-known α-TiP solid. As was already exemplified in the case of zirconium-based MOFs, the final inorganic building unit results from the competition between both types of ligands, the organic and inorganic ones. Upon switching from carboxylate to α-hydroxycarboxylate, catecholate, or phosphonates ligands, the strength of coordination increases, hence disfavoring the presence of inorganic ligands. Similar to the case of titanium phosphate chemistry under hydrothermal conditions, this effect might, of course, be counterbalanced through an increase of the pH, favoring inorganic condensation.

elements.content: Crystal structure of MIL-168, a 1D coordination chain.
elements.clean_text: 4  Crystal structure of MIL-168, a 1D coordination chain.

elements.content: Thus, in order to favor the formation of more condensed inorganic units with DOBDC, drastic modifications of the synthetic conditions were applied. An increase of the pH did not lead, however, to any crystalline materials. Thus, we selected another possibility, which consists of the use of preformed titanium oxo clusters as a source of titanium-containing oxo/hydroxo species, hoping that, upon complexation with the title linkers, one might form more condensed building units. The tetrameric titanium oxalate formulated as Ti4O4(ox)7(pipH2)3 (ox = oxalate and pipH2 = piperazinium), which already contains μ2-oxo-bridged titanium ions, was thus prepared. Upon reaction with H2DOBDC in water (a solvent that, of course, favors the appearance of hydroxo or oxo ligands), a fourth microcrystalline solid, later labeled MIL-169, was isolated (). The structure was again solved by powder XRD (see Figure S6 for the final Rietveld plot), taking into account local information gained from solid-state NMR. This solid crystallizes in a triclinic setting, with one oxygen atom on an inversion center, one titanium ion, and two halves of a DOBDC ligand. It contains also half of a piperazinium ion and two water molecules in the general position, leading to the formula Ti2O­(DOBDC)2(H2O)2(pipH2)·2H2O, in agreement TGA (Figure S12 and Table S1), chemical analysis as well as 1H and 13C NMR ( and S25−S27). Each titanium ion is chelated by two DOBDC ligands through the six-membered ring involving phenolate and carboxylate groups already observed in MIL-167, MIL-168, and “NTU-9-like”. It is worth noting that the titanium ions are associated in Ti2O11 dimers of octahedra bridged by a μ2-oxo group and exhibit terminal water molecules (a). These dimers are then connected to each other through four DOBDC ligands to afford anionic layers (b), which are further separated by hydrogen-bonded piperazinium ions and free water molecules to define the whole structure (c). Note that the dimer is reminiscent of the titanyl chains of metal octahedra with alternating short (1.80 Å) and long (2.29 Å) Ti–O distances. Hence, upon “forcing” the conditions, it appears possible to incorporate inorganic ligands within titanium α-hydroxycarboxylate coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text: Thus, in order to favor the formation of more condensed inorganic units with DOBDC, drastic modifications of the synthetic conditions were applied. An increase of the pH did not lead, however, to any crystalline materials. Thus, we selected another possibility, which consists of the use of preformed titanium oxo clusters as a source of titanium-containing oxo/hydroxo species, hoping that, upon complexation with the title linkers, one might form more condensed building units. The tetrameric titanium oxalate formulated as Ti4O4(ox)7(pipH2)3 (ox = oxalate and pipH2 = piperazinium), which already contains μ2-oxo-bridged titanium ions, was thus prepared. Upon reaction with H2DOBDC in water (a solvent that, of course, favors the appearance of hydroxo or oxo ligands), a fourth microcrystalline solid, later labeled MIL-169, was isolated (). The structure was again solved by powder XRD (see Figure S6 for the final Rietveld plot), taking into account local information gained from solid-state NMR. This solid crystallizes in a triclinic setting, with one oxygen atom on an inversion center, one titanium ion, and two halves of a DOBDC ligand. It contains also half of a piperazinium ion and two water molecules in the general position, leading to the formula Ti2O(DOBDC)2(H2O)2(pipH2)⋅2H2O, in agreement TGA (Figure S12 and Table S1), chemical analysis as well as 1H and 13C NMR ( and S25-S27). Each titanium ion is chelated by two DOBDC ligands through the six-membered ring involving phenolate and carboxylate groups already observed in MIL-167, MIL-168, and "NTU-9-like". It is worth noting that the titanium ions are associated in Ti2O11 dimers of octahedra bridged by a μ2-oxo group and exhibit terminal water molecules (a). These dimers are then connected to each other through four DOBDC ligands to afford anionic layers (b), which are further separated by hydrogen-bonded piperazinium ions and free water molecules to define the whole structure (c). Note that the dimer is reminiscent of the titanyl chains of metal octahedra with alternating short (1.80 Å) and long (2.29 Å) Ti-O distances. Hence, upon "forcing" the conditions, it appears possible to incorporate inorganic ligands within titanium α-hydroxycarboxylate coordination polymers.

elements.content: Crystal structure of MIL-169. (a) Ti2(DOBDC)4O­(H2O)2 dimer. (b) 2D coordination network. (c) Stack of anionic layers separated by piperazinium ions and water molecules.
elements.clean_text: 5  Crystal structure of MIL-169. (a) Ti2(DOBDC)4O(H2O)2 dimer. (b) 2D coordination network. (c) Stack of anionic layers separated by piperazinium ions and water molecules.

elements.content: The thermal behavior of all solids was evaluated by TGA and temperature-dependent powder XRD analysis under oxygen and air, respectively. As expected, the TGA curves of all solids but MIL-169 present a weight loss in the low-temperature regime (50 °C < T < 150 °C) associated with the elimination of entrapped solvent molecules (Figure S12). Temperature-dependent powder XRD analysis reveals that this solvent departure is associated with strong shifts in the position of the Bragg peaks in MIL-169 and “NTU-9-like”, while no noticeable change occurs for MIL-167 (Figures S8, S9, and S11). This is in line with the structure of these solids: MIL-169 and “NTU-9-like” are 2D compounds and thus prone to shrink upon solvent departure (especially when the solvent molecules are located between the layers). MIL-167, which adopts an interpenetrated 3D structure, appears to be rather rigid toward desorption.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Behavior and Sorption Properties

The thermal behavior of all solids was evaluated by TGA and temperature-dependent powder XRD analysis under oxygen and air, respectively. As expected, the TGA curves of all solids but MIL-169 present a weight loss in the low-temperature regime (50 °C < T < 150 °C) associated with the elimination of entrapped solvent molecules (Figure S12). Temperature-dependent powder XRD analysis reveals that this solvent departure is associated with strong shifts in the position of the Bragg peaks in MIL-169 and "NTU-9-like", while no noticeable change occurs for MIL-167 (Figures S8, S9, and S11). This is in line with the structure of these solids: MIL-169 and "NTU-9-like" are 2D compounds and thus prone to shrink upon solvent departure (especially when the solvent molecules are located between the layers). MIL-167, which adopts an interpenetrated 3D structure, appears to be rather rigid toward desorption.

elements.content: At higher temperature, all solids present a similar feature, with combustion of the organic moieties occurring around 250 °C (Figure S12) and associated with the complete collapse of the structures (Figures S8–S11). It is worth noting that this temperature is significantly lower than the ones observed for titanium carboxylates such as MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2. This is likely to arise from the intrinsic reactivity of phenolate ligands with oxidants (here dioxygen), as was already observed with other cations.
elements.clean_text: At higher temperature, all solids present a similar feature, with combustion of the organic moieties occurring around 250 °C (Figure S12) and associated with the complete collapse of the structures (Figures S8-S11). It is worth noting that this temperature is significantly lower than the ones observed for titanium carboxylates such as MIL-125 and MIL-125-NH2. This is likely to arise from the intrinsic reactivity of phenolate ligands with oxidants (here dioxygen), as was already observed with other cations.

elements.content: The permanent porosity of MIL-167 was finally assessed after activation at 150 °C overnight. No noticeable adsorption of N2 at −195 °C was detected. In contrast, adsorption of CO2 at near-ambient conditions (15 °C) leads to a type I isotherm indicative of microporous character, with a maximal adsorption capacity of around 2.1 mmol g–1 at 20 bar (). These results can be understood in light of the structure of MIL-167: although this framework is quite open, both interpenetration and the presence of entrapped bulky diethylmethylammonium cations drastically decrease the accessible pore volume, leading finally to a modest sorption capacity.
elements.clean_text: The permanent porosity of MIL-167 was finally assessed after activation at 150 °C overnight. No noticeable adsorption of N2 at -195 °C was detected. In contrast, adsorption of CO2 at near-ambient conditions (15 °C) leads to a type I isotherm indicative of microporous character, with a maximal adsorption capacity of around 2.1 mmol g-1 at 20 bar (). These results can be understood in light of the structure of MIL-167: although this framework is quite open, both interpenetration and the presence of entrapped bulky diethylmethylammonium cations drastically decrease the accessible pore volume, leading finally to a modest sorption capacity.

elements.content: CO2 sorption isotherms of MIL-167 at 15 °C.
elements.clean_text: 6  CO2 sorption isotherms of MIL-167 at 15 °C.

elements.content: The optical properties of MIL-167, MIL-168, MIL-169, and “NTU-9-like” were evaluated by diffuse-reflectance spectral measurements (see the Supporting Information for details), and the corresponding absorption spectra are shown in , together with the ones for MIL-125-NH2 and the H4DOBDC ligand. The absorption spectrum of the H4DOBDC ligand presents two main absorption bands centered at about 250 and 400 nm. In sharp contrast, all coordination polymers built up from this ligand present roughly similar spectra, with a band centered at 250 nm, together with a broad band covering the 300–600 nm window. This result was, as developed in the introduction, expected, and confirmed the occurrence of LMCT typical of titanium phenolate systems. This significantly differs from titanium carboxylate compounds (see MIL-125-NH2 in ), whose absorption bands in the visible range are typically associated with purely organic electronic levels.
elements.clean_text:
Optical Properties and Photocatalytic Tests

The optical properties of MIL-167, MIL-168, MIL-169, and "NTU-9-like" were evaluated by diffuse-reflectance spectral measurements (see the Supporting Information for details), and the corresponding absorption spectra are shown in , together with the ones for MIL-125-NH2 and the H4DOBDC ligand. The absorption spectrum of the H4DOBDC ligand presents two main absorption bands centered at about 250 and 400 nm. In sharp contrast, all coordination polymers built up from this ligand present roughly similar spectra, with a band centered at 250 nm, together with a broad band covering the 300-600 nm window. This result was, as developed in the introduction, expected, and confirmed the occurrence of LMCT typical of titanium phenolate systems. This significantly differs from titanium carboxylate compounds (see MIL-125-NH2 in ), whose absorption bands in the visible range are typically associated with purely organic electronic levels.

elements.content: Diffuse-reflectance spectra of MIL-167, MIL-168, MIL-169, and “NTU-9-like” in comparison with H4DOBDC and MIL-125-NH2.
elements.clean_text: 7  Diffuse-reflectance spectra of MIL-167, MIL-168, MIL-169, and "NTU-9-like" in comparison with H4DOBDC and MIL-125-NH2.

elements.content: These results prompted us to test the charge-transport ability of the title solids. Time-resolved microwave conductivity (TRMC) measurements were thus carried out on MIL-167. The solid was initially ground and drop-cast on a quartz plate, and the excitation wavelength was set to 500 nm, i.e., close to the absorption maximum. As shown in Figure S18, the photoconductance was found to be low (ηΣμ ∼ 2.10–5 cm2 V–1 s–1), on the whole similar to the one of MIL-125 derivatives, and no improvement was observed upon irradiation in the UV range (340 nm; Figure S19). This result probably arises from the fact that such a structure does not offer a long-range pathway suitable for electronic conduction as a possible consequence of the isolated titanium metal centers.
elements.clean_text: These results prompted us to test the charge-transport ability of the title solids. Time-resolved microwave conductivity (TRMC) measurements were thus carried out on MIL-167. The solid was initially ground and drop-cast on a quartz plate, and the excitation wavelength was set to 500 nm, i.e., close to the absorption maximum. As shown in Figure S18, the photoconductance was found to be low (ηΣμ ~ 2.10-5 cm2 V-1 s-1), on the whole similar to the one of MIL-125 derivatives, and no improvement was observed upon irradiation in the UV range (340 nm; Figure S19). This result probably arises from the fact that such a structure does not offer a long-range pathway suitable for electronic conduction as a possible consequence of the isolated titanium metal centers.

elements.content: Finally, preliminary tests were carried out to assess the photocatalytic activity of MIL-167, MIL-169, and “NTU-9-like” for hydrogen production. The solids were suspended in a solution of water and triethylamine (acting as a proton source and a sacrificial electron donor, respectively) in acetonitrile at 30–35 °C, and hydrogen evolution was monitored under constant light irradiation (see the Supporting Information for details). The results are shown in and compared with those obtained for MIL-125-NH2. The latter was indeed already shown to act as a moderate photocatalyst in similar conditions. Under UV irradiation (λ = 280 nm), a noticeable production of hydrogen was detected for MIL-167, while no activity was found for MIL-169 and “NTU-9-like” solids, suggesting that the microporosity might play a role in achieving an efficient conversion. The reaction rate was found to be initially 2.6 higher for MIL-167 than for MIL-125-NH2 (reaction rate = 2.9 and 7.7 μmol h–1 for MIL-125-NH2 and MIL-167, respectively), but the activity decreases with time, suggesting deactivation of the catalyst, although powder XRD analysis indicates that the structure is maintained with some splits of the diffraction peaks (Figure S3), likely because of a symmetry lowering (from cubic to tetragonal; Figure S4) associated with different pore contents. Upon switching to visible-light irradiation (λ = 385 nm), a slight decrease of hydrogen production is observed for MIL-125-NH2 (Figure S20), while no more hydrogen is detected for MIL-167 (data not shown). These preliminary experiments indicate that good visible-light absorption ability is not the prime criterion in determining the catalytic activity of titanium-based MOFs for hydrogen production. In the case of MIL-167, it is especially not yet fully understood why, in spite of the observed LMCT, no catalytic activity under visible illumination could be achieved. Deeper investigations are thus requested to shed some light on this behavior.
elements.clean_text: Finally, preliminary tests were carried out to assess the photocatalytic activity of MIL-167, MIL-169, and "NTU-9-like" for hydrogen production. The solids were suspended in a solution of water and triethylamine (acting as a proton source and a sacrificial electron donor, respectively) in acetonitrile at 30-35 °C, and hydrogen evolution was monitored under constant light irradiation (see the Supporting Information for details). The results are shown in  and compared with those obtained for MIL-125-NH2. The latter was indeed already shown to act as a moderate photocatalyst in similar conditions. Under UV irradiation (λ = 280 nm), a noticeable production of hydrogen was detected for MIL-167, while no activity was found for MIL-169 and "NTU-9-like" solids, suggesting that the microporosity might play a role in achieving an efficient conversion. The reaction rate was found to be initially 2.6 higher for MIL-167 than for MIL-125-NH2 (reaction rate = 2.9 and 7.7 μmol h-1 for MIL-125-NH2 and MIL-167, respectively), but the activity decreases with time, suggesting deactivation of the catalyst, although powder XRD analysis indicates that the structure is maintained with some splits of the diffraction peaks (Figure S3), likely because of a symmetry lowering (from cubic to tetragonal; Figure S4) associated with different pore contents. Upon switching to visible-light irradiation (λ = 385 nm), a slight decrease of hydrogen production is observed for MIL-125-NH2 (Figure S20), while no more hydrogen is detected for MIL-167 (data not shown). These preliminary experiments indicate that good visible-light absorption ability is not the prime criterion in determining the catalytic activity of titanium-based MOFs for hydrogen production. In the case of MIL-167, it is especially not yet fully understood why, in spite of the observed LMCT, no catalytic activity under visible illumination could be achieved. Deeper investigations are thus requested to shed some light on this behavior.

elements.content: Photocatalytic activity of MIL-167, MIL-169, “NTU-9-like”, and MIL-125-NH2 (30 mg) for hydrogen production: hydrogen evolution as a function of the time of reaction at 40 °C upon irradiation at 280 nm.
elements.clean_text: 8  Photocatalytic activity of MIL-167, MIL-169, "NTU-9-like", and MIL-125-NH2 (30 mg) for hydrogen production: hydrogen evolution as a function of the time of reaction at 40 °C upon irradiation at 280 nm.

elements.content: Upon systematic investigation under solvothermal conditions of the reactivity of titanium­(IV) precursors with H4DOBDC, four crystalline phases were isolated and characterized, highlighting the high degree of structural diversity of this system. Their structural analysis revealed that, in sharp contrast with the case of pure carboxylate ligands and due to the strong coordination ability of the α-hydroxycarboxylate moieties, the formation of coordination polymers built up from isolated titanium ions surrounded solely by organic ligands is favored. The appearance of more condensed motifs, including inorganic oxo bridges, requires specific conditions, such as the use of an aqueous reaction medium and precondensed inorganic reactants. Thanks to LMCT, all solids present strong absorption in the visible range, much broader than the titanium carboxylate systems. Preliminary experiments reveal that such an optical feature does not lead, however, to a direct improvement of the photocatalytic performance under visible light and that further studies are needed to gain benefits from such characteristics.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Upon systematic investigation under solvothermal conditions of the reactivity of titanium(IV) precursors with H4DOBDC, four crystalline phases were isolated and characterized, highlighting the high degree of structural diversity of this system. Their structural analysis revealed that, in sharp contrast with the case of pure carboxylate ligands and due to the strong coordination ability of the α-hydroxycarboxylate moieties, the formation of coordination polymers built up from isolated titanium ions surrounded solely by organic ligands is favored. The appearance of more condensed motifs, including inorganic oxo bridges, requires specific conditions, such as the use of an aqueous reaction medium and precondensed inorganic reactants. Thanks to LMCT, all solids present strong absorption in the visible range, much broader than the titanium carboxylate systems. Preliminary experiments reveal that such an optical feature does not lead, however, to a direct improvement of the photocatalytic performance under visible light and that further studies are needed to gain benefits from such characteristics.

These results can be understood in light of the structure of MIL-167: although this framework is quite open, both interpenetration and the presence of entrapped bulky diethylmethylammonium cations drastically decrease the accessible pore volume, leading finally to a modest sorption capacity.

metadata.title:
Investigating the Case of Titanium(IV) Carboxyphenolate
Photoactive Coordination Polymers
